      <title>We often know when drought or floods will strike. So let's act before they do | Neil Marsland</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/13/el-nino-farmers-frontline-drought-floods-building-resilience</link>
      <description><p>Climate change and the current strong El Niño are creating costly humanitarian crises. But it’s so much cheaper to avert disaster through building resilience</p><p>The life of a farmer in Somalia is never easy and, right now, it’s about as hard as it gets. The weather <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2015/nov/23/somaliland-climate-change-drought-cyclones-life-or-death-challenge">no longer seems to follow recognisable patterns</a> and the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/mar/16/drought-high-temperatures-el-nino-36m-people-africa-hunger">El Niño phenomenon</a> is exacerbating the crisis.</p><p>At 47 years old, Maymuno Madobe Cali has seen it all: drought, floods, disease and conflict. She knows only too well how a precious but fragile livelihood can vanish. She lost 26 goats the last time floods and water-borne diseases came to Boodaale and she is praying the same will not happen to her remaining 11 animals. With seven people in her family, another spell of bad weather could push her to the brink. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/13/el-nino-farmers-frontline-drought-floods-building-resilience">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p><strong>Havant, Hampshire</strong> As I watched, a woodlouse blundered into a translucent tripline and the web vibrated</p><p>My gardening gloves had lain abandoned in the shed for several months as the cold, wet spring had thwarted any plans to plant out early crops. When I went to put them on they pulled away from the rough-planked shed wall with a sound like ripping Velcro.       <description><p>Microbe populations make up 11-31% of living matter in the ocean seabed, but decline significantly as oceans warm<br></p><p>Microbes are hardly the poster-children of climate change, but they have far more impact than polar bears on Earth’s carbon cycle – and therefore on our climate. A new study published Friday in <a href="http://advances.sciencemag.org/content/2/4/e1500961"><em>Science Advances</em></a> finds that seabed bacteria and archaea (which look like bacteria but have very different genetics and biochemistry) are sensitive to climate. Because their habitat covers 65% of the entire globe, they form a huge part of the biosphere and are important in the regulation of carbon in the deep ocean, which affects long-term climate change.</p><p>The microbes in question are packed together in the top 15 centimeters of the deep ocean seabed, like rush hour commuters in a city metro, up to a million times more abundant than in the sunless ocean water, or buried in deeper layers of seabed sediments. Their city-like crowding is fueled by a sparse sordid snow of excrement and microscopic dead bodies from life in the upper ocean, far above them.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/climate-consensus-97-per-cent/2016/may/06/deep-sea-microbes-may-be-key-to-oceans-climate-change-feedback">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Despite regular coastal cleanups around the world, the problem of ocean garbage continues. Now, two Australians say they’ve found the solution – the Seabin</p><p>By now, reports that our oceans are turning into swirling garbage dumps should come as no surprise. There are some <a href="http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2015/01/150109-oceans-plastic-sea-trash-science-marine-debris/">5.25tn pieces of floating plastic debris in the oceans</a> right now, and it’s <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/13/science/earth/plastic-ocean-waste-levels-going-up-study-says.html?_r=1">estimated</a> that some 8m metric tons of plastic waste enter global waters every year. A researcher recently likened it to lining up five grocery bags of trash on every foot of coastline around the world. The US is adjacent to the largest of the five ocean “garbage patches” – it’s estimated the <a href="http://marinedebris.noaa.gov/info/patch.html">Great Pacific Garbage Patch</a>, which extends from the coast of North America to a few hundred miles off the coast of Japan, contains <a href="http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2014/04/140414-ocean-garbage-patch-plastic-pacific-debris/">some 480,000 pieces of plastic per square kilometer</a>.</p><p>Now, two surfers from Australia say they may have the solution.       <description><p>It began with Fairtrade. Almost 30 years later, with hundreds of different certifications is it time to question what they all do and who benefits?</p><p>In 1988, the first Fairtrade label, <a href="http://maxhavelaar.nl/english" rel="nofollow">Max Havelaar</a>, was applied to packs of Mexican coffee sold in Dutch supermarkets. At the time, using a product label to say something about standards in a supply chain was revolutionary, but today it is routine. The <a href="http://www.ecolabelindex.com/" rel="nofollow">Ecolabel Index</a> currently lists 463 certifications in 199 countries.</p><p>On the face of it, certifications on everything from fish to timber can be seen as progress, promising higher standards and transparency in the pursuit of sustainability. But what purpose are the certification labels actually serving? Can we assume that they are beneficial to producers? Do consumers understand what’s behind a certification label, and does it even matter if they do? These were some of the questions asked at a recent roundtable discussion hosted by the Guardian and supported by <a href="http://www.mondelezinternational.com/" rel="nofollow">Mondelēz International</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/mar/10/fairtrade-labels-certification-rainforest-alliance">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>As oil prices bottom out and fossil fuels no longer offer strong returns, investment dollars are starting to move to renewable energy</p><p>Divestment – the decision to voluntarily reduce one’s fossil fuel investments – has been a hot button <a href="http://www.arabellaadvisors.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Measuring-the-Global-Divestment-Movement.pdf">topic of discussion</a> since 2011, when university students began calling on their institutions to remove fossil fuels from their portfolios. Divestment arguments have often focused on the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/feb/02/oxbridge-academics-call-for-morally-sound-university-investments">morality of investments</a>, but the economic value of divestment has recently become hard to ignore.</p><p>In January, portfolio planner Advisor Partners reported that, between 2014 and 2015, <a href="http://www.advisorpartners.com/uploads/4/8/5/3/48535043/350.org_statement.pdf">New York City’s biggest pension fund</a> lost $135m because of its fossil fuel holdings.
